Jewish families
Exterior views
Colorado
Aspen (Colo.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Exterior view of the house of Harris and Leah Sheffel Kobey, 200 West Main Street in Aspen, Colorado, circa 1915. The Victorian house has a tree in front and a fence around the house, and there is snow on the ground. The house was later completely destroyed by fire.

Exterior views
Colorado
Aspen (Colo.)
Merchants
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Exterior view of the two story brick Kobey Shoe and Clothing Co. store in Aspen, Colorado. Two boys stand outside in the entranceway. A sign at the top of the building reads "MEN'S and BOYS OUTFITTERS." Another sign reads "The KOBEY SHOE and CLOTHING CO." and a sign on the awning reads "THE HOME OF THE BEST MADE WEARING APPA[REL]" Clothing and other sales goods can be seen in the window displays.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Sheffel sisters pose for a formal group portrait at the studio of Mrs. B.B. Chase in Denver, Colorado in October 1902. Back row: Millie (Mrs. Joseph Levy), Jennie (Mrs. Joseph Washer), Rose (Mrs. David Greinetz). Front row: Mary (Mrs. M. Joseph Gottstein), Birdie (Mrs. M. Schraiberg), and Leah (Mrs. Harris Kobey, mother of Dorothy Dokes Kobey Berry).
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: On matting below photograph: "Mrs. B. B. Chase, 910 - 16th St., Denver, Colo." Typed caption by Ted Harsham, with information from Dorothy ''Dokes'' Kobey Berry: "Sheffel Sisters - October 1902. Millie, Jennie, Rose, Mary, Birdie, Leah. Millie (Joseph Levy), Jennie (Joseph Washer), Rose (David Greinetz), Mary (M. Joseph Gottstein), Birdie (M. Schraiberg), Leah (Harris Kobey). Collection of and identification on the reverse by Dorothy ''Dokes'' Kobey Berry."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The adult children of Samuel A. and Mary Rachofsky Kobey pose for a group portrait at a family reunion in Washington Park in Denver, Colorado. Colorado
Aspen (Colo.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two informal photographs of Dorothy (Dokes) Kobey Berry and her children, grandchildren, and great grandson. In the upper photograph, Dokes poses with her children in front of the exterior of a house on July 22, 2000. Standing from left to right are Joan, Harold, Dokes, and Susan. The photograph was taken July 22, 2000. In the lower photograph, Dokes poses with one of her children, a grandchild, and a great grand-child in May 2000. From left to right are Mark (grandson), Dokes holding great-grandson Steven, and Harold (son).

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The interior of the Kobey Shoe and Clothing Company store in Aspen, Colorado. Five employees pose behind counters; from left to right are Henrietta (Hetty) Reiss Kobey, Mark Kobey, Albert L. Kobey, Homer Van Loon, and John Parsons. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Typed caption by Ted Harsham, with identifying information from Dorothy ''Dokes'' Kobey Berry: "Family of Harris and Leah Sheffel Kobey about 1903 in Aspen, Colorado. Standing: Leah, Harris holding Leon, housekeeper (?). Children in front: Philip, Rebecca. Gelatin silver print. 9.3 cm wide x 10 cm high, mounted on card 12.5 cm x 12.5 cm, photographer unknown. In the collection of Dorothy ''Dokes'' Kobey Berry, Denver, Colorado from the papers of her father, Harris Kobey. Handwritten on the back in the hand of Dokes Berry: 'Leah + Harris Kobey in Aspen. Philip, Leon + Rebecca, housekeeper on right. Scanned from the original, cropped, enlarged, enhanced, and captioned by Ted Harsham - July 16, 2002."

The Sheffel Kobey family poses for a group portrait in the yard of a house in Aspen, Colorado. Back row, left to right: Leah Sheffel Kobey, Harris Kobey (holding Leon), and the housekeeper. Philip and Rebecca Kobey stand in front.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Actors in the Aspen High School senior class play "It Pays to Advertise" pose for a group portrait at the Isis Theater in Aspen, Colorado on April 18, 1923. Among the players were Dorothy Kobey as Conessa de Beaurain, Silas Kobey as Ambrose Peale, and Nathan Kobey as Cyrus Martin.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Kobey Kids as Graduates
Digitized Materials, Dorothy (Dokes) Kobey Berry Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Harsham, Ted E.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Kobey family
Berry, Dorothy Kobey,--1905-2009
Kobey, Silas M.,--1904-1991
Kobey, Nathan Reiss,--1905-1974
Jews
Jewish women
Jewish men
Academic costume
Group portraits
Colorado
Aspen (Colo.)
High school students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Written on the area around the photograph is "At The Time of My Valedictory," "Si" and "Na," "1923," and "The Kobey Kids as Graduates."

Silas, Dorothy, and Nathan Kobey (left to right) pose for a formal portrait in Aspen, Colorado in 1923. Dorothy, whose nickname was "Dokes," is seated, and Silas and Nathan stand on either side. All three wear graduation caps and gowns. Dorothy and Silas Kobey were the children of Harris and Leah Sheffel Kobey. Nathan Kobey was the son of Benjamin and Hattie Reiss Kobey, as well as a cousin of Dorothy and Silas Kobey. Dorothy was the valedictorian of the 1923 graduating class of Aspen High School in Aspen, Colorado.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Miriam Rachofsky Kobey and Grandchildren Hannah Shwayder Berry
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Dorothy (Dokes) Kobey Berry Papers, Digitized Materials
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Harsham, Ted E.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Miriam Rachofsky Kobey and her grandchildren (from left to right, Rebecca, Miriam holding Silas, Philip, and Leon) pose in front of an ivy-covered trellis in Aspen, Colorado. Immigrants Abraham and Miriam (Mary) Kobey began their life in Colorado in Central City. The devout couple became vegetarians for a time while living there because kosher meat transported from Denver often arrived spoiled. After they moved to Denver, Abraham worked as a rabbi and sofer, or scribe, and Miriam became a highly respected midwife, often performing her services free for poor women. The parents of the children are Harris and Leah Sheffel Kobey.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Kobey family
Kobey, Miriam Rachofsky,--1840-1921

Dorothy, whose nickname was "Dokes," and Silas Kobey were the children of Harris and Leah Sheffel Kobey.
